GP1.history: The Buriram International Circuit, also known as Chang International Circuit, is a modern track that debuted in MotoGP in 2018.
GP1.fun_fact: It was the first MotoGP circuit in Thailand.

GP2.history: Termas de Río Hondo Circuit has hosted MotoGP since 2014 and is known for its fast layout.
GP2.fun_fact: The circuit is situated near a hot springs area.

GP3.history: Circuit of the Americas in Austin, Texas, joined the MotoGP calendar in 2013.
GP3.fun_fact: Known for its iconic 133-foot climb to the first corner.

GP4.history: The Lusail International Circuit has hosted the season opener for MotoGP since 2004.
GP4.fun_fact: It hosts MotoGP races under floodlights.

GP5.location: Spain Circuito de Jerez - Ángel Nieto
GP5.history: A historic circuit that has been part of the MotoGP calendar since 1987.
GP5.fun_fact: It was renamed in honor of Spanish rider Ángel Nieto.

GP6.history: The Le Mans Bugatti Circuit has been a regular on the MotoGP calendar since 1969.
GP6.fun_fact: The circuit is known for unpredictable weather conditions.

GP7.history: Silverstone is one of the oldest circuits in MotoGP, hosting races since 1977.
GP7.fun_fact: It has one of the longest lap distances on the MotoGP calendar.

GP8.history: Motorland Aragón joined MotoGP in 2010 and has become a fan favorite.
GP8.fun_fact: Designed by renowned architect Hermann Tilke.

GP9.history: Mugello has been a regular fixture in MotoGP since 1994.
GP9.fun_fact: Known for its high-speed straights and scenic Tuscan backdrop.

GP10.history: The 'Cathedral of Speed,' Assen has hosted races since 1949.
GP10.fun_fact: The only circuit to host a MotoGP race every year since the championship began.

GP11.history: Sachsenring has been a part of the MotoGP calendar since 1998.
GP11.fun_fact: It features one of the shortest lap distances on the calendar.

GP12.history: Brno has hosted MotoGP races since 1987 and is a favorite among riders.
GP12.fun_fact: Known for its elevation changes and sweeping corners.

GP13.history: Red Bull Ring returned to MotoGP in 2016 after a long hiatus.
GP13.fun_fact: One of the fastest circuits on the calendar.

GP14.history: Balaton Park is a new addition to the MotoGP calendar.
GP14.fun_fact: The circuit is designed with safety and sustainability in mind.

GP15.history: A staple of MotoGP since 1992, known for its technical layout.
GP15.fun_fact: Also used as a popular F1 testing venue.

GP16.location: San Marino Misano World Circuit Marco Simoncelli
GP16.history: Misano has hosted MotoGP since 1980 and was renamed to honor Marco Simoncelli.

GP17.history: Motegi has been part of MotoGP since 1999.
GP17.fun_fact: Also known as the Twin Ring Motegi due to its dual-track design.

GP18.fun_fact: Located on the island of Lombok, offering stunning ocean views.

GP19.history: Phillip Island has been a MotoGP favorite since 1989.
GP19.fun_fact: Known for its scenic ocean backdrop and high-speed corners.

GP20.history: Sepang has been part of MotoGP since 1999.
GP20.fun_fact: One of the most challenging circuits due to its heat and humidity.

GP21.history: Algarve joined MotoGP in 2020 as a substitute venue.
GP21.fun_fact: Known for its undulating layout, earning it the nickname 'Portimão Rollercoaster.'

GP22.history: Valencia Circuit Ricardo Tormo has been a staple in the MotoGP calendar and often hosts the season finale.
GP22.fun_fact: The circuit is named after Spanish rider Ricardo Tormo, a two-time world champion.
